title: Riot needs to decide who their core audience is.
body:
Because I sure as hell don't know. Are we still a Moba like Dota with 30-40 min games or are we chasing the Overwatch and PubG crows that want to be done fast and on to the next round?

At the end of the day you cannot cater to both audiences with the same game. It is really too bad that Dominion hadn't been made into it's own minigame with its own champion roster and development team. 

As it is League is hamstrung between people who liked the old game length and people who enjoy the new short vicious games. Choose one or the other boys but stop trying to be everything to everyone.

While true, DOTA never hit the mass appeal that League did. Granted, I'm not going to say this is a bad thing. However, it has made DOTA far smaller than it _could_ have been. Again, not a bad thing! It's sort of the difference between a game company making money and a game company making MONEY.

League's half-and-half has been both it's biggest strength and greatest weakness. The pub balance makes it more welcoming to newcomers and allows for some changes to be made toward that lowest common denominator while the pro changes keeps it strategic (regardless of how players might feel). However, it's never gone fully in either direction, creating a massive pain point for both sides that ends up causing more and more problems as time goes on. We've started seeing it as early as 2015 actually, where pub changes do little to solve problems while pro changes have to be massive and sweeping.

My goal isn't to dismiss DOTA. It is, however, a point that DOTA has focused on the pro scene and ends up with a far better game for the top tier of play yet makes the game tougher to get into. Comparatively, League always goes for the midpoint between both and never truly satisfies either, which I find to be problematic. In much the same way people want Riot to have DOTA-tier diversity but League-tier newbie friendliness, so too does Riot want a deep and hardcore pro scene like DOTA but with the mass market appeal of what League is/was.

And yet despite this, there were plenty of chances to dethrone League. Hell, if anything, DOTA2 had a fantastic chance because it did and offered a lot of things different from league such as free cosmetics (before the crafting system like 2 decades later) and all heroes unlocked. However, the difficulty made it harder for people to get into DOTA2 even with an objectively better tutorial.


> In light of these facts, it is actually a testiment to how good Dota's gameplay is that it did manage to achieve the second highest success by a huge margin compared with all other mobas. 

If you want to cement anything as League's success, it was never earnestly the gameplay. The gameplay was nice for people, sure, but it's not what truly made league shine. It's a combination of:

* Rapid change. A new character every two weeks near the beginning of League's lifespan meant there was always something new as well as balance changes.
* A winning F2P model that became something of the standard among most MOBAs in the industry. A truly "free" game. 
* A blooming esport scene that began to grow and captured a teenage audience.

You see the same thing with Fortnite: Rapid changes, a winning model and a blooming community that captures a young demographic the way S2 league did. And these rapid changes also were fraught with problems in both early and later seasons for both casuals and pros. It's always been an issue, it's just gotten too big to ignore at this point.

 
> Your premise is wrong. 
> You overestimate how easy League is to get into. Both are just as archaic and bewlidering to a new player.

Climbing a mountain is still hard but a mountain that takes a day to climb is easier than the mountain that takes a year to climb.

League wasn't simple, sure, but it had greatly less painful mechanics even with DOTA's superior tutorial. DOTA had a lot of design people misconstrued as clunky that required fine-practice most people didn't want to get into. Missile speeds, turn times, denying, stacking, etc. League simplified these mechanics just enough to keep the depth while still being easier than DOTA to get into.

Your point about HotS also misses the biggest factor to HotS's lack of success: Time. HotS officially released June 2nd, 2015. This is _six years_ after League's debut and the renaissance of the MOBA genre.  While we don't have league numbers, 2015 is around the time where DOTA2 peaked according to steam charts and just before the MOBA genre began to decline as a whole. HotS could have had some of the greatest gameplay in the world but it was to League what Playstation All Stars was to Smash Bros: A halfhearted attempt that was too little, too late. The few who found league too complex moved to hots.

League has a lot of factors that contributed to it's success but I'm still going to stand that the greatest was providing a tough/deep strategy game while also keeping it simple enough that a casual audience could enter it, while the biggest "casual" competition coming 6+ years after League's release.
